name: TheAtlantic
text: 1.4 million new cases; 106,000 hospitalizations; 15,966 deaths. Even in a horrible year, this week stands out, writes @COVID19tracking. https://t.co/6wJZCNl27G

name: TheAtlantic
text: "When they say the 2020 election was stolen, Trumpists are expressing their view that the votes of rival constituencies should not count, even though they understand, on some level, that they do," @AdamSerwer writes: https://t.co/ABHwmIhVcU

name: TheAtlantic
text: "It’s not just Donald Trump, many Republican state leaders, and several thousand COVID-19 deniers who have waged a war against scientific comprehension. America’s virus illiteracy spans the partisan divide," @DKThomp writes: https://t.co/l9bBuKW6Zz

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @sarahzhang: My latest on vaccines: 

What the next six months are going to look like. It will be a weird and confusing and sometimes chaotic in-between period—vaccine purgatory, if you will 

https://t.co/uCEMYWQUmc

name: TheAtlantic
text: “We carry a million stories within us at any given time, and depending what they are, they can help us, lead us astray, or get us through the day.” @tepingchen talks with Oliver Munday about writing characters who are full of longing: https://t.co/hQB3EIfrta

name: TheAtlantic
text: SPONSORED: After a car accident caused serious injury, Arlette Leveque changed her approach to well-being. Here’s how she’s helping others do the same. @Humana https://t.co/yRHrhGBXR9 https://t.co/YgDAEDBQ5f

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Vaccines are not an off switch. It will take several months to vaccinate enough Americans to resume normal life, and this interim could prove long, confusing, and chaotic," writes @sarahzhang: https://t.co/n3lb3uKdWA

name: TheAtlantic
text: Millions of people have lost friends to COVID-19. For "The Friendship Files," @julieebeck talks with one of them, Mary-Ann, who shares what made her friend Baby so special and reflects on the struggle of mourning a personal loss during a global crisis. https://t.co/gcGgbiKni0

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @TheAtlPhoto: Hopeful Images From 2020 - An annual tradition - a collection of uplifting images from the past 12 months—an effort to seek out and recognize some of the abundant joy and kindness present in the world around us, even in the midst of a truly awful year. https://t.co/aSveIEbGJ4 https://t.co/2fVAwTrhp5

name: TheAtlantic
text: Books about immigrant life embrace complexity, in this week's #TheAtlanticBooksBriefing. From @cray_kate: https://t.co/cavufhv1OC

name: TheAtlantic
text: The people who lived through Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath have a story to tell—of rumors, betrayal, and one of the most misunderstood events in American history. Listen to "Floodlines," named New York magazine's best podcast of 2020. https://t.co/ZOowxYIU7H

name: TheAtlantic
text: 1/ This is the worst week of the pandemic yet. The United States set records in all three metrics that gauge severity, including a total of 1.4 million new cases and 15,966 deaths as of Wednesday. And it could get worse, writes @COVID19Tracking. https://t.co/BySTXjZy28

name: TheAtlantic
text: 2/ The virus has torn through long-term-care facilities. The number of deaths jumped 27 percent the week of December 3. States reported the highest number of new cases—51,574—in these facilities since @COVID19Tracking started collecting these data in May: https://t.co/WOWDEobUii

name: TheAtlantic
text:
3/ As COVID-19 has overwhelmed hospitals, the lack of clear bioethical guidelines has forced doctors to make wrenching life-and-death decisions on the fly. The result has been chaos and unnecessary suffering, @jordan_kisner writes.
https://t.co/xg4DyBYrdg

name: TheAtlantic
text:
4/ An FDA advisory committee voted Thursday to authorize the first vaccine against COVID-19, but until Americans have broad access to it, quarantining is the main thing keeping us healthy. So why aren’t more Americans doing it? @olgakhazan reports:
https://t.co/DL07pQmQGL

name: TheAtlantic
text: 5/ A vaccine is also not an off switch for the coronavirus pandemic, @sarahzhang warns. The next six months will almost certainly bring delays, fights over priority, and questions about how immune the newly vaccinated are and how they should behave. https://t.co/xjhGfx1Xn3

name: TheAtlantic
text:
6/ We are already seeing signs of “vaccine nationalism,” in which nations prioritize their domestic needs at the expense of others. This accelerated efforts to develop drugs—but the pandemic will not end without equal distribution, @YasmeenSerhan writes.
https://t.co/c0ZjP62zvX

name: TheAtlantic
text: 7/7 “With enough effort and cooperation, the holidays next year could feel almost like normal,” @jameshamblin writes. “The exact timeline—and how much hardship we endure in the interim—is up to us.“  https://t.co/AJdyUAWnYQ

name: TheAtlantic
text: "It’s not just Donald Trump, many Republican state leaders, and several thousand COVID-19 deniers who have waged a war against scientific comprehension. America’s virus illiteracy spans the partisan divide," @DKThomp writes: https://t.co/YWgV8q5ZyT
